Description: Dome-shaped weight carved from dark grey hard stone, likely basalt; carinated dome type with well-defined edge; of truncated conical shape, with flat base and convex top; smoothed surface; complete.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Oriental Institute, University of Chicago. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Dome-shaped weights, including sub-domed types, represent one of the most common weights found in Naukratis, and elsewhere in Egypt (Petrie 1886, Pl. XXIII, “sub-domed” type; Cour-Marty 1990, 25, fig. 3, fig. 13). They are often made out of igneous rock such as basalt and diorite – which is the case for this specimen. Already present in the Old Kingdom, this type is particularly common on Late Period sites in the Delta (Cour-Marty 1990, 25, fig. 26). Dome-shaped weights are more often associated to the Egyptian standard deben-kedet (usually around 90-95 g and 9-9,5 g for this type) and their multiples or sub-multiples. However a lighter unit, around 8g, is also noticed and could correspond to other standards such as the Near Eastern shekel or the Greek stater (Cour-Marty 1990, 24-25, fig. 22-24; Kroll 2003, 317; van Alfen 2002, 184, n. 654). This is probably the case of this specimen which could correspond more specifically to a sixth of a shekel (?). Cour-Marty, M.-A. 1989.
